history.content:
As someone who went this route in order to fulfill a haas prerequisite, I can say that personally 134 prepared me an incredible amount for cs 70, to the point where basically the whole probability section I only did problems for practice and didn't need to learn any new concepts at all, allowing me to earn an A with far less work than many of my classmates. This redundancy may not be a good thing for you, however, as you may be left with the feeling that you have wasted some of your time. As professor Sahai said, building mathematical maturity is important for the course, but I feel like previous exposure to the material is also incredibly helpful. I would say if you really need a good grade in cs70 that this is a great route to take, otherwise I would advise against it unless you want to learn more continuous probability than is covered in cs70. 

----------------

I don't think it's necessary to take STAT 134 before CS 70. The basic probability is not the hard part of CS 70. The lecture and discussion teach you everything you need to solve probability questions.

As someone who went this route in order to fulfill a haas prerequisite, I can say that personally 134 prepared me an incredible amount for cs 70, to the point where basically the whole probability section I only did problems for practice and didn't need to learn any new concepts at all, allowing me to earn an A with far less work than many of my classmates. This redundancy may not be a good thing for you, however, as you may be left with the feeling that you have wasted some of your time. As professor Sahai said, building mathematical maturity is important for the course, but I feel like previous exposure to the material is also incredibly helpful. I would say if you really need a good grade in cs70 that this is a great route to take, otherwise I would advise against it unless you want to learn more continuous probability than is covered in cs70.

children.subject: I haven't taken those courses, but I believe that the overlap material between the philosophy department and CS70 is only on propositional logic, which 70 spends a week or less on.
Which is one of the easiest parts of CS70 imo

I took philosophy 140B (deals with computability and incompleteness) as a breadth class after 70 and was able to follow it well as it delved much deeper into the topic. (Sometimes painfully deep :) )

From Prof Mancosu, I heard 140A also delves equally deep into its topics, so I'd recommend it after 70 if you're interested.

tl;dr don't take Phil 140AB before 70 imo
In a similar vein, would people recommend taking philosophy 12A, intro to logic or philosophy 140A, Intermediate logic, as prep for CS70? Would there be any meaningful carry over?

I took 134 before 70. It helps a little (very little).

I don't think it's worth it to go a single iota out of your way to try to take 134 before CS70. The advantage you get is miniscule, the approaches to the material, and what each course places emphasis on are very different. 

If you are going to take 134 regardless, and if taking it before CS70 does not hinder you in any way then go for it.

I took 134 before 70. My advice depends on your current needs and your academic interests:

If you are L&S CS and have a borderline CS GPA and need every slight advantage you can get, then 134 will give you a definite advantage. In CS 70, the best way to get a high grade is to first MASTER the material, then GET GOOD AT SOLVING PROBLEMS. The problems are still difficult, but you do not have to spend nearly as much time reading the notes, freeing up your time to focus on doing more problems. 

If you can do without a slight advantage and are still planning on taking 134 regardless (to take classes like STAT 135, 151A, 154, 150 or help prepare for CS 189), you'll get a lot more out of the course after taking 70. Many of the top performers in Stat 134 had taken Math 55 beforehand, and 70 is decidedly more rigorous than Math 55.

history.content:
The strong recommendation for CS students is to take 126 after 70 instead of taking Stat 134. EECS 126 leans on 70 more and teaches you more than 134 can without assuming 70.  EE16A and EE16B should be sufficient mathematical maturity preparation to engage successfully with 70. Seeing specific material before is not generally a good strategy for preparing for a course. In the absence of suitable preparation, it can be actively harmful.  

That said, if it is a matter of helping conquer apprehension regarding probability after having taken 16A and 16B (for the prerequisite mathematical maturity), then sitting in on Stat 134 and doing the homeworks is fine. I think that just sitting-in on courses, attending lectures and discussions, and doing problems to learn without any fear at all can be helpful for people. Everyone faces a different mix of challenges --- for some folks, it is the stress of new material in the face of a GPA-threshold that degrades performance. Finding ways to overcome the stress is useful, and if that means sitting-in on a course, then sit in on a course. The important thing is just to not confuse things. Preparation is preparation. Stress is stress. These are different things.

Hi, I was wondering if people would recommend taking Stat 134 before 70? I have read through several threads and have seen different responses. Either people think that it is helpful for mastery, or people think it is too in depth to be necessary and that the probability taught in 70 is different enough that it is not worth it. 

Thanks for the help!
history.subject: Stat 134 for CS 70?
